snippet.textDisplay: I'm sorry, but as much as I like pretty much every genre and I can play as much NES as PS3, I don't see the appeal of a text adventure game... If I want to read a book, I prefer to have a physical book in my hand than reading a lot of text on my TV. I guess the music helps a lot in the experience department (here I would guess it's its greatest asset). I just don't see what is appealing about it. Same is true for other visual novels. I guess I should play one before judging, but the prospect of having no actual gameplay is not really exciting in itself...
snippet.textOriginal: I'm sorry, but as much as I like pretty much every genre and I can play as much NES as PS3, I don't see the appeal of a text adventure game... If I want to read a book, I prefer to have a physical book in my hand than reading a lot of text on my TV. I guess the music helps a lot in the experience department (here I would guess it's its greatest asset). I just don't see what is appealing about it. Same is true for other visual novels. I guess I should play one before judging, but the prospect of having no actual gameplay is not really exciting in itself...

snippet.textDisplay: Well, the thing that sets Text Adventures/Visual Novels apart from regular books is, most of them are interactive, like a choose-your-own-adventure book. For example, if you remove the puzzle element from 999, it's just a visual novel, but it has questions that you need to answer in it that drastically affect the game's ending.
snippet.textOriginal: Well, the thing that sets Text Adventures/Visual Novels apart from regular books is, most of them are interactive, like a choose-your-own-adventure book. For example, if you remove the puzzle element from 999, it's just a visual novel, but it has questions that you need to answer in it that drastically affect the game's ending.

snippet.textDisplay: Seems like Radical Dreamers is valuable mostly for providing back stories that help bridge Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross, along with providing a basis for the story and soundtrack of Chrono Cross. Still, it's really nice to hear how nice the songs in Radical Dreamers sound. Yasunori Misudia is absolutely brilliant. :)
snippet.textOriginal: Seems like Radical Dreamers is valuable mostly for providing back stories that help bridge Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross, along with providing a basis for the story and soundtrack of Chrono Cross. Still, it's really nice to hear how nice the songs in Radical Dreamers sound. Yasunori Misudia is absolutely brilliant. :)

snippet.textDisplay: I haven't played too many text adventures, but this one was alright. I couldn't help but be slightly disappointed though, seeing as it's (loosely) connected to my favorite game of all time. The soundtrack has very few tracks, but they're all quite memorable and most of them were remade for Chrono Cross.

I couldn't help but be slightly disappointed though, seeing as it's (loosely) connected to my favorite game of all time. The soundtrack has very few tracks, but they're all quite memorable and most of them were remade for Chrono Cross.

snippet.textDisplay: @daniel cardoso I wholeheratedly agree with the campfire part. Cross was born in that scene, so it's normal some fans think of Cross as a fanfic of Trigger. Cross is polarizing but, the way I found the experience to be most enjoyable is to think of it as a "Serge" story. Don't bother with any other characters and just focus on Serge. The moment I finally get the whole time travel fuckery (pardon my french), I saw the story in a new light and loved it all the more. And if I could, I'd also have removed the whole "Greenpeace" aspect of the game. The preachy, moralizing Dwarves part and the "Give us back our planet" bit in the end game dungeon (was it Dinopolis or Terra Tower?). I mean, it didn't make sense since the world was pretty clean and nature untouched, or, if you want to add that message they should have made the setting more steam-punky (but just to make sense, mind you). The problem I have with the "Earth" is that her motivation for.....doing her thing (againg, massive spoilers, so not saying anything) is that it was more Tree-loving than existential nightmare. And I think it was a wasted opportunity, since it's a plot thread that is blurted by Lucca if you have her fighting Lavos' second form, so you can't say it's not canon.
snippet.textOriginal: @daniel cardoso I wholeheratedly agree with the campfire part. Cross was born in that scene, so it's normal some fans think of Cross as a fanfic of Trigger. Cross is polarizing but, the way I found the experience to be most enjoyable is to think of it as a "Serge" story. Don't bother with any other characters and just focus on Serge. The moment I finally get the whole time travel fuckery (pardon my french), I saw the story in a new light and loved it all the more. And if I could, I'd also have removed the whole "Greenpeace" aspect of the game. The preachy, moralizing Dwarves part and the "Give us back our planet" bit in the end game dungeon (was it Dinopolis or Terra Tower?). I mean, it didn't make sense since the world was pretty clean and nature untouched, or, if you want to add that message they should have made the setting more steam-punky (but just to make sense, mind you). The problem I have with the "Earth" is that her motivation for.....doing her thing (againg, massive spoilers, so not saying anything) is that it was more Tree-loving than existential nightmare. And I think it was a wasted opportunity, since it's a plot thread that is blurted by Lucca if you have her fighting Lavos' second form, so you can't say it's not canon.

snippet.textDisplay: @sammanzhi Thank you very much.

snippet.textDisplay: @andrey22 I'd agree with that play order.
snippet.textOriginal: @andrey22 I'd agree with that play order.

snippet.textDisplay: @sammanzhi It was tied off and then dropped off a bridge. It's proto Cross if you will (and one of the characters IS well..."one of the cast from Trigger" to avoid spoilers, so you can't deny the tie in with trigger) and to be honest, instead of the 42 character madness we got in cross, I'd much rather we had the 3-man party of Dreamers. But I'm ranting, sorry, what I meant to say is that Cross recognizes the full plot of Dreamers and integrates it inot it's story but you can skip RD and not miss a thing because it doesn't add any new information that wasn't in Cross. Hell, if anything, it makes things more confusing by adressing the Masamune as "The devil sword" and the Accaccia Dragoons out of nowhere! So I say that, to get the Chrono Experience one should play: Trigger first, Cross second and RD third. It's a canon spin-off and I can find the exact text in the game that proves it, if youu want.
snippet.textOriginal: @sammanzhi It was tied off and then dropped off a bridge. It's proto Cross if you will (and one of the characters IS well..."one of the cast from Trigger" to avoid spoilers, so you can't deny the tie in with trigger) and to be honest, instead of the 42 character madness we got in cross, I'd much rather we had the 3-man party of Dreamers. But I'm ranting, sorry, what I meant to say is that Cross recognizes the full plot of Dreamers and integrates it inot it's story but you can skip RD and not miss a thing because it doesn't add any new information that wasn't in Cross. Hell, if anything, it makes things more confusing by adressing the Masamune as "The devil sword" and the Accaccia Dragoons out of nowhere! So I say that, to get the Chrono Experience one should play: Trigger first, Cross second and RD third. It's a canon spin-off and I can find the exact text in the game that proves it, if youu want.

snippet.textDisplay: @andrey22 It's tied to Chrono Cross. Chrono Cross was made after RD and was modeled after RD. You can make it canon if you want, especially if you take into account that CC's entire plot is centered around parallel universes. Just because it's also tied to Trigger doesn't mean that the story doesn't run into Cross. If anything it sort of bridges the two.
snippet.textOriginal: @andrey22 It's tied to Chrono Cross. Chrono Cross was made after RD and was modeled after RD. You can make it canon if you want, especially if you take into account that CC's entire plot is centered around parallel universes. Just because it's also tied to Trigger doesn't mean that the story doesn't run into Cross. If anything it sort of bridges the two.

snippet.textDisplay:
@sammanzhi Sorry to be "that guy" but I have to say that it's not Chrono Cross. In fact it's canon that the story in RD is a parallel universe. When you get to Chronopolis and find the Research Centre, if you inspect one of the compuers, you'll find a log that is a word for word replay of the very begining of RD that ends with a cliff note from the researcher saying that this book confirm the hypothesis of multiple realities.
So the Chrono series was already rocking the multiple realities theory way before Bioshock Infinite had come out.
snippet.textOriginal:
@sammanzhi Sorry to be "that guy" but I have to say that it's not Chrono Cross. In fact it's canon that the story in RD is a parallel universe. When you get to Chronopolis and find the Research Centre, if you inspect one of the compuers, you'll find a log that is a word for word replay of the very begining of RD that ends with a cliff note from the researcher saying that this book confirm the hypothesis of multiple realities.
So the Chrono series was already rocking the multiple realities theory way before Bioshock Infinite had come out.

snippet.textDisplay: Well, the personalities are a bit different, but I'd say Kid's is pretty close and Serge, well Serge never really had a personality in Cross. Lynx is definitely more venomous and woeful. You're right that it's not canon, but you can notice things in RD that carried over to Cross for sure.
snippet.textOriginal: Well, the personalities are a bit different, but I'd say Kid's is pretty close and Serge, well Serge never really had a personality in Cross. Lynx is definitely more venomous and woeful. You're right that it's not canon, but you can notice things in RD that carried over to Cross for sure.

snippet.textDisplay: @daniel cardoso I didn't say it served as a complement to Cross' story, but it does sort-of fill that role because, as you said, it's what Cross is based off of. You get more insight into Lynx, Serge, Kid, Viper Manor, the Acacia Dragoons, and the frozen flame. Even though the story differs in RD and Cross it doesn't mean you can't use RD to read more into Cross if you so choose.
snippet.textOriginal: @daniel cardoso I didn't say it served as a complement to Cross' story, but it does sort-of fill that role because, as you said, it's what Cross is based off of. You get more insight into Lynx, Serge, Kid, Viper Manor, the Acacia Dragoons, and the frozen flame. Even though the story differs in RD and Cross it doesn't mean you can't use RD to read more into Cross if you so choose.
